required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Prevention and Early Detection of Cervical Cancer Through Self-Administered Screening
clinical_study.official_title: Prevention and Early Detection of Cervical Cancer Through Self-Administered Screening in the Community

brief_summary.textblock: This study examines prevention and early detection of cervical cancer through self-administration screening of patients in Western Uganda. The cervix is the opening of the uterus or womb, which is the organ that supports babies before they are born. There are simple tests that let doctors know whether or not patients have cells that may become cancer. Some of the tests determine whether patients have an increased risk for cervical disease, but they do not actually confirm that they have it: these are called "screening" tests. This study may help researchers determine how to best deliver cervical cancer prevention services using the HPV test.

detailed_description.textblock:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVES:
I. To establish the acceptance and correlates of self-collected human papillomavirus (HPV)-ribonucleic acid (RNA) testing among women in the rural Ugandan community as well as the incidence and determinants of successful completion of the cervical cancer screening cascade from self-collected HPV testing to receipt of results.
II. To ascertain the frequency and determinants of successful acquisition of treatment among women who have HPV detected on self-collected swabs in rural Uganda.
III. To derive population-based estimates of the prevalence of high-risk HPV and cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) detected through community-based screening employing self-collected HPV RNA testing in rural Uganda.
OUTLINE:
Patients receive a specimen kit for collection of HPV samples. Patients complete questionnaire before and after collection HPV samples. Patients may also participate in an interview about general ideas in improving the screening and treatment process. Patients with positive results, undergo treatment for cervical cancer.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of participants who complete screening
primary_outcome.description: The absolute number of participants successfully completing screening.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of women 25-49 years of age who complete screening
primary_outcome.description: Overall proportions of women 25-49 years old successfully completing cervical cancer screening.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of participants who receive treatment after a positive screening result
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of participants who receive treatment after screening positive for high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) will be calculated with a 95% confidence interval.

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of participants with positive, high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV)
primary_outcome.description: Prevalence of participants with positive high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV)

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of participants with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN2)+
primary_outcome.description: Proportion of participants with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN2)+

arm_group.description: Patients receive a specimen kit for collection of HPV samples. Patients complete questionnaire before and after collection HPV samples. Patients may also participate in an interview about general ideas in improving the screening and treatment process. Patients with positive results, undergo treatment for cervical cancer.

intervention.description: Undergo collection of cervical samples for HPV testing

study_pop.textblock: Women in the three Ugandan districts (Kiboga, Kyankwanzi and Hoima) who access screening during the community health campaigns

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women in the three Ugandan districts (Kiboga, Kyankwanzi and Hoima) who access screening during the community health campaigns
- Age 25-49 years
- Resident in the study district
- Provision of informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Clinical signs and symptoms of cancer of the cervix

facility.name: Makerere University College of Health Sciences School of Medicine
